definitions: extremely hungry with a desperate need to eat
showing extreme eagerness to obtain or consume something greedily
examples: The ravenous wolves hunted through the night for prey
After hiking all day, we were ravenous for dinner
The company showed ravenous appetite for acquiring smaller competitors
She had a ravenous desire for knowledge and books

definitions: speaking or behaving in a wild, irrational manner often due to delirium
expressing extreme enthusiasm or admiration about something
examples: The fever left him raving about imaginary dangers
She was raving mad after the shocking betrayal
Critics were raving about the new restaurant downtown
The audience gave raving reviews of the performance

definitions: completely destroyed or demolished down to ground level
examples: The old factory was razed to make room for apartments
The earthquake razed entire neighborhoods to the ground

definitions: able to be reached physically or arrived at
able to be contacted or communicated with successfully
examples: The summit is reachable only by experienced climbers
Keep medicines in cabinets not reachable by children
She's always reachable by phone during business hours
The customer service team is reachable through multiple channels

definitions: opposing political or social progress and favoring return to previous conditions
examples: The party's reactionary policies alienated younger voters completely
His reactionary views on education belonged to another century

definitions: showing a tendency to undergo chemical reaction with other substances
acting in response to situations rather than creating or controlling them
examples: Sodium is highly reactive with water producing hydrogen gas
The reactive metals must be stored carefully under oil
Their reactive management style only addressed problems after arising
The team needs proactive rather than reactive security measures

definitions: clear and easy to read or decipher
interesting and enjoyable to read as written material
examples: Please use readable handwriting on all medical forms
The new font makes the website much more readable
Her latest novel is highly readable despite complex themes
The biography provides readable accounts of historical events

definitions: made real or brought into actual existence
became fully aware of something as fact
examples: Her dreams were finally realised after years of work
The architect's vision was realised in the stunning building
He realised his mistake only after submitting the report
They realised the true extent of damage during inspection

definitions: made real or brought into actual existence
became fully aware of something as fact
examples: Their investment goals were realized through careful planning
The company realized huge profits from the new product
She suddenly realized she had forgotten her passport
We realized the importance of backup systems too late

definitions: restored to life or consciousness after apparent death
examples: The reanimated corpse terrorized the village in the movie
Scientists reanimated frozen tissue samples for research purposes

definitions: located at or near the back of something
examples: The rear entrance provides access to the parking lot
Passengers in rear seats must wear safety belts

definitions: rising up on hind legs or raising the front part upward
examples: The rearing horse nearly threw its inexperienced rider off
A rearing cobra is an extremely dangerous sight to encounter

definitions: located at the very back or furthest position from front
examples: The rearmost compartment stores emergency supplies and equipment
Soldiers in the rearmost ranks couldn't see the action

definitions: directed toward or situated at the rear or back
examples: The rearward motion of the train surprised waiting passengers
Install rearward facing cameras for better parking assistance

definitions: based on logical thinking rather than emotion or impulse
examples: She presented a reasoned argument for policy changes needed
His reasoned approach to problems earned colleagues' respect greatly

definitions: using logical thinking to draw conclusions or make decisions
examples: The reasoning minds of scientists solve complex problems systematically
Children develop reasoning abilities through education and experience

definitions: made to feel less afraid, anxious, or doubtful about something
examples: Patients felt reassured by the doctor's confident explanation
The reassured investors decided to maintain their positions

definitions: serving to remove doubts, fears, or anxiety in others
examples: Her reassuring words calmed the frightened child down quickly
The test results were reassuring for the worried parents

definitions: showing desire to resist authority, control, or convention
showing defiance of normal standards of behavior or dress
examples: The rebellious teenager constantly challenged school rules and policies
Rebellious provinces threatened the stability of the empire
Her rebellious fashion choices shocked conservative family members
The artist's rebellious spirit influenced an entire generation

definitions: brought back to life or born again after death
experiencing spiritual renewal or fundamental transformation in life
examples: The mythical phoenix is reborn from its own ashes
The reborn vampire retained no human memories or emotions
She felt reborn after overcoming her addiction successfully
The reborn company emerged stronger from bankruptcy proceedings

definitions: stubbornly refusing to obey rules or follow instructions from authority
examples: The recalcitrant student refused to complete any assigned homework
Recalcitrant nations faced economic sanctions from the international community

definitions: moving back or away from a previous position gradually
gradually becoming smaller, weaker, or less noticeable over time
examples: The receding floodwaters revealed extensive damage to buildings
His receding hairline became more noticeable each passing year
The receding threat allowed residents to return home safely
Receding gums can indicate serious dental health problems

definitions: able to be received or accepted in a particular way
representing money owed to a business by its customers
examples: The signal is receivable only with specialized antenna equipment
These documents are receivable as evidence in court
Accounts receivable increased significantly during the holiday season
The company's receivable invoices totaled over two million

definitions: generally accepted as true or worthy by most people
examples: The received wisdom about diet has changed dramatically recently
She challenged received notions about women in science fields

definitions: willing to consider or accept new suggestions and ideas openly
able or ready to receive something, especially signals or stimuli
examples: The manager was receptive to employee suggestions for improvement
Students are most receptive to learning in comfortable environments
The receptive cells in our eyes detect different light wavelengths
Plants have receptive tissues that absorb nutrients from soil

definitions: set back or indented from the surrounding surface or wall
examples: Recessed lighting creates subtle ambiance throughout the modern home
The recessed doorway provided shelter from the pouring rain

definitions: tending to go back or recede from prominence
relating to genetic traits masked by dominant alleles unless inherited from both parents
examples: The recessive tide exposed hidden rocks along the shore
Her naturally recessive personality made public speaking extremely difficult
Blue eyes result from recessive genes inherited from both parents
The recessive trait appeared in one quarter of offspring

definitions: able to have electrical energy restored for repeated use
examples: These rechargeable batteries last for hundreds of charging cycles
The rechargeable flashlight provides reliable emergency lighting at home

definitions: given, felt, or done in return between two parties
related to mathematical quantities whose product equals one
examples: Their reciprocal respect made the partnership highly successful
Countries signed reciprocal trade agreements benefiting both economies
The reciprocal of 5 is 1/5 in mathematics
Students learned about reciprocal fractions in algebra class

definitions: acting without thinking or caring about dangerous consequences
examples: His reckless driving endangered everyone on the busy highway
The company's reckless spending led to inevitable bankruptcy

definitions: brought back from waste into useful condition or cultivation
reformed from an immoral or debased state to better condition
examples: The reclaimed wetlands now support diverse wildlife populations again
Artists create beautiful furniture from reclaimed wood materials
The reclaimed prisoner became a respected community leader eventually
Many reclaimed addicts help others overcome similar struggles

definitions: marked by withdrawal from society and preference for solitary life
examples: The recluse author hadn't left her mountain home for years
His recluse lifestyle worried friends who rarely saw him

definitions: seeking solitude and avoiding the company of other people habitually
examples: The reclusive billionaire rarely attended any public events
Her reclusive nature made forming friendships extremely difficult

definitions: able to be identified from previous encounters or knowledge
examples: Her voice was instantly recognisable on the phone recording
The building's recognisable architecture made it a city landmark

definitions: acknowledged as valid, legal, or having official status
identified as something or someone encountered or known before
examples: She's a recognised expert in marine biology research worldwide
The university offers only recognised qualifications for international students
He recognised his childhood friend despite twenty years apart
The symptoms were recognised as early signs of illness

definitions: able to be identified from previous encounters or knowledge
examples: The actor wore sunglasses to be less recognizable publicly
These recognizable symptoms indicate a common cold developing

definitions: acknowledged as valid, legal, or having official status
identified as something or someone encountered or known before
examples: The treatment is recognized by major medical associations globally
He's a recognized authority on constitutional law matters
She recognized several faces from the previous conference
The software recognized the voice pattern almost instantly

definitions: restored to friendship or harmony after conflict or estrangement
made oneself accept something unpleasant but unavoidable
examples: The reconciled couple renewed their wedding vows last summer
The reconciled accounts showed no discrepancies in spending
He finally reconciled himself to living in the city
She reconciled her dreams with practical career choices

definitions: making things compatible or consistent with each other
examples: Reconciling different viewpoints requires patience and open communication
The reconciling process between nations took several years

definitions: built again after being damaged or destroyed
pieced together from fragments or partial evidence to form complete picture
examples: The reconstructed bridge uses modern earthquake-resistant design features
Surgeons reconstructed her face after the terrible accident
Police reconstructed the crime scene using witness testimonies carefully
Scientists reconstructed dinosaur behavior from fossil evidence

definitions: relating to rebuilding or restoring something damaged to functional state
examples: Reconstructive surgery helped burn victims regain normal appearance
The reconstructive efforts after war required international assistance

definitions: set down in writing or other permanent form for reference
officially measured as the highest, lowest, fastest, or best ever
examples: All meetings must have recorded minutes for legal compliance
The conversation was recorded for quality assurance purposes
This summer had recorded temperatures exceeding previous heat records
The athlete achieved recorded speeds never seen before

definitions: able to be recovered, regained, or restored after loss
examples: Most deleted files are recoverable with proper software tools
The lawyer assured them the damages were legally recoverable

definitions: obtained again after losing possession or control of something
returned to normal health after illness or injury
examples: Police recovered stolen artwork worth millions from warehouse
She recovered her composure after the shocking news
The patient fully recovered from surgery within six weeks
Markets recovered quickly after the initial pandemic shock

definitions: in process of returning to normal health after illness or addiction
examples: The recovering patient needs plenty of rest and nutrition
Support groups help recovering addicts maintain their sobriety

definitions: relating to activities done for enjoyment in leisure time
examples: The park offers many recreational activities for families visiting
Recreational fishing requires a valid license from state authorities

definitions: relating to or affecting the rectum in the digestive system
examples: The doctor prescribed rectal suppositories for treating constipation
Rectal temperature readings are most accurate for infants

definitions: having the shape of a rectangle with four right angles
examples: The rectangular swimming pool fits perfectly in the backyard
Most smartphones have rectangular screens for optimal viewing

definitions: corrected or made right after identifying an error or problem
examples: The accounting error was quickly rectified before audit began
Engineers rectified the design flaw in next product version

definitions: lying down in a position of rest or comfort
examples: The recumbent figure on the couch appeared deeply asleep
Recumbent bicycles provide comfortable exercise for seniors with back issues
